articles.headline: Talk of Medicare Changes Could Open Way to Budget Pact
articles.snippet: Recent statements from both Democrats and Republicans show a possible way forward in curbing Medicare costs, suggesting a lingering, if slight, chance for a budget bargain.
articles.abstract: Recent statements from both Democrats and Republicans show a possible way forward in curbing Medicare costs, suggesting a lingering, if slight, chance for a budget bargain.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As they explore possible fiscal deals, President Obama and Congressional Republicans have quietly raised the idea of broad systemic changes to Medicare that could produce significant savings and end the polarizing debate over Republican plans to privatize the insurance program for older Americans.
articles.byline: By Jackie Calmes and Robert Pear

articles.headline: In Cyprus, Feeling the Pain of a Bailout
articles.snippet: The reaction of much of the financial world to the Cyprus crisis has been muted, but on the island, the damage and pain are resulting in a rising anger.
articles.abstract: The reaction of much of the financial world to the Cyprus crisis has been muted, but on the island, the damage and pain are resulting in a rising anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: NICOSIA, Cyprus — Shaking his head in disgust, Stavros Agrotis, an independent financial executive here, peered Thursday morning at the stock chart of Bank of Cyprus on his computer screen — a bright red line sloping sharply downward, before it stopped trading altogether in recent days.

articles.headline: Controls on Capital Come Late to Cyprus
articles.snippet: Cyprus would be better off now had huge amounts of money not flowed into its banks in 2008 and 2009.
articles.abstract: Cyprus would be better off now had huge amounts of money not flowed into its banks in 2008 and 2009.
articles.lead_paragraph: Capital controls came to Cyprus this week, a few years after they should have arrived — when it needed controls to stem the flow of hot money into the country’s banks.

articles.headline: Cyberattacks Seem Meant to Destroy, Not Just Disrupt
articles.snippet: Corporate leaders have long feared hacking in service of fraud or spying, but now a new threat has taken hold: attackers, possibly with state support, who seem bent on destruction.
articles.abstract: Corporate leaders have long feared hacking in service of fraud or spying, but now a new threat has taken hold: attackers, possibly with state support, who seem bent on destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: American Express customers trying to gain access to their online accounts Thursday were met with blank screens or an ominous ancient type face. The company confirmed that its Web site had come under attack.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Riding Wave of Popularity, Craft Brewers Ask Congress for a Tax Cut
articles.snippet: Hundreds of brewers went to Washington this week to seek aid that they said would help them brew more beer and hire more workers.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of brewers went to Washington this week to seek aid that they said would help them brew more beer and hire more workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — They came to an opening night beer blast at the National Air and Space Museum, 4,000 strong in baseball caps and T-shirts, to look at the Wright Brothers’ airplane and drink Citizen by DC Brau, which also makes a wryly named hometown brew, Corruption.

articles.headline: Sprint Nears a U.S. Deal to Restrict China Gear
articles.snippet: Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to accept restrictions from American law enforcement officials on the companies’ ability to pick telecommunications suppliers.
articles.abstract: Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to accept restrictions from American law enforcement officials on the companies’ ability to pick telecommunications suppliers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Seeking to address national security concerns, Sprint Nextel and SoftBank, its Japanese suitor, are expected to enter an agreement with American law enforcement officials that will restrict the combined company’s ability to pick suppliers for its telecommunications equipment and systems, government officials said on Thursday.

articles.headline: Taliban Spread Terror in Karachi as the New Gang in Town
articles.snippet: The grab for influence and power in the city shows that the Taliban have been able to extend their reach across Pakistan, not just in the country’s frontier regions.
articles.abstract: The grab for influence and power in the city shows that the Taliban have been able to extend their reach across Pakistan, not just in the country’s frontier regions.
articles.lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — This seaside metropolis is no stranger to gangland violence, driven for years by a motley collection of armed groups who battle over money, turf and votes.
articles.byline: By Declan Walsh and Zia ur-Rehman

articles.headline: Insider Inquiry at SAC Reaches Into Higher Ranks
articles.snippet: When Michael S. Steinberg became the most senior employee to be ensnared in the investigation, his charmed life came undone.
articles.abstract: When Michael S. Steinberg became the most senior employee to be ensnared in the investigation, his charmed life came undone.

articles.headline: After 21 Years, NPR Is Ending ‘Talk of the Nation’
articles.snippet: NPR will end the call-in show “Talk of the Nation” this summer and urge radio stations to replace it with the Boston-based program “Here and Now,” which has a magazine style.
articles.abstract: NPR will end the call-in show “Talk of the Nation” this summer and urge radio stations to replace it with the Boston-based program “Here and Now,” which has a magazine style.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOSTON — NPR is ending the 21-year-old call-in radio show “Talk of the Nation” and will encourage local stations to replace it with an expanded version of “Here and Now,” an afternoon news broadcast that is produced here, the organization announced on Friday.

articles.headline: New Phone by Facebook to Showcase Its Network
articles.snippet: Facebook will introduce a version of Google’s Android software system next week that is modified to put the social network front and center on a smartphone. The software will make its debut on a handset made by HTC, said a Facebook employee who ha...
articles.abstract: Facebook will introduce a version of Google’s Android software system next week that is modified to put the social network front and center on a smartphone. The software will make its debut on a handset made by HTC, said a Facebook employee who had been briefed on the product.
articles.byline: By Brian X. Chen and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: Bad Directors and Why They Aren’t Thrown Out
articles.snippet: The track record of the board of Hewlett-Packard is calamitous, and yet they have retained their jobs, because efforts to remove such directors are not always made and rarely succeed.
articles.abstract: The track record of the board of Hewlett-Packard is calamitous, and yet they have retained their jobs, because efforts to remove such directors are not always made and rarely succeed.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the annals of shareholder democracy, it’s hard to imagine a more compelling case against a company’s directors than those who presided over the serial management calamities that have plagued the computer giant Hewlett-Packard in recent years.
